member.name: T:RT.Util.CommandLine.CommandLineParser
member.summary: Implements a command-line parser that can turn the commands and options specified by the user on the command line into a strongly-typed instance of a specific class. See remarks for more details.

remarks.para: The following conditions must be met by the class wishing to receive the options and parameters:

item.description: It must be a reference type (a class), must have , and it must have a parameterless constructor (unless it has subcommands, see below).

description.para: Every field in the class must have one of the following custom attributes:

item.description: (allowed for all supported types except bool) — specifies that the parameter is positional; the user specifies the value(s) in place without an option preceding it.

(allowed for all supported types) — specifies that the parameter invoked by an option, e.g. -x, which may or may not be followed by a value. (This does not imply that the parameter is necessarily optional.)
(allowed for enum types only) — specifies that the parameter can be invoked by one of several options, which are specified on the enum values in the enum type.
— specifies that shall completely ignore the field.

description.para: Each field may optionally have any of the following custom attributes:

item.description: (allowed for all supported types except bool) — specifies that the parameter must be specified by the user. For a string[] field, it means that at least one value must be specified.
— specifies that the option or command does not appear in the help screen generated by CommandLineParser.

description.para: Each field in the class must be of one of the following types:

item.description: string, any integer type, float, double, or any nullable version of these. The field can be positional () or not ().
string[]. The field can be positional () or not (), but if it is positional, it must be the last positional parameter.
bool. The field must have an and cannot be positional or mandatory.

description.para: Any enum type. There are three ways that enum types can be used. To explain these, the following enum type declaraction is used as an example:
— The user can specify a single parameter (e.g. plain or xml) to select an enum value. Every value in the enum type must have a to specify the name by which that enum value is selected:

item.description: — The user can select an enum value by specifying an option followed by a parameter that identifies the enum value (e.g. -f plain or -f xml). As above, every value in the enum type must have a to specify the name by which that enum value is selected.

description.para: — The user can select an enum value by specifying just an option (e.g. -p or -x). Every value in the enum type must have an to specify the option by which that enum value is selected:
A parameter on the attribute determines whether the user is allowed to specify only one enum value or multiple (which will be combined using bitwise or).

item.description: If the field is optional, the enum value that corresponds to the field’s initial (default) value may omit the or .

description.para: Every field must have documentation or be explicitly marked with (except for fields that use or ). For every field whose type is an enum type, the values in the enum type must also have documentation or , except for the enum value that corresponds to the field’s default value if the field is not mandatory.
Documentation is provided in one of the following ways:

item.description: Monolingual, translation-agnostic (unlocalizable) applications use the to specify documentation directly.

description.para: Translatable applications must declare methods with the following signature:

The first parameter must be of the same type as the object passed in for the applicationTr parameter of . The name of the method is the name of the field or enum value followed by Doc. The return value is the translated string.

item.description: and can be used together. However, a positional field can only be made mandatory if all the positional fields preceding it are also mandatory.

remarks.para: Subcommands can be implemented by using derived classes. For example, in order to allow the user to invoke commands of the following form:
remarks.code: MyTool.exe create new_item MyTool.exe rename old_name new_name
remarks.para: you would declare the following classes:
In this example, we have omitted the documentation attributes, but in practice they would be required. The following points are of note here:

description.para: The class CmdBase is abstract to indicate that the subcommand is mandatory. The class could be made non-abstract to indicate that the subcommand is optional.

The class CmdBase does not need to have a parameterless constructor because only CmdCreate and CmdRename would actually be instantiated by CommandLineParser. However, if it were non-abstract, it would need a parameterless constructor.
Parameters that pertain to all subcommands can be added in CmdBase and the user would specify those before the command name.
You can have any arbitrary multi-level class hierarchy. Only classes marked with become subcommands.

member.name: M:RT.Util.CommandLine.CommandLineParser.Parse``1(System.String[],RT.Util.Lingo.TranslationBase,System.Func{RT.Util.Consoles.ConsoleColoredString,RT.Util.Consoles.ConsoleColoredString})
member.summary: Parses the specified command-line arguments into an instance of the specified type. See the remarks section of the documentation for for features and limitations.
member.typeparam: The class containing the fields and attributes which define the command-line syntax.
member.param: The command-line arguments to be parsed.

Specifies the application’s translation object which contains the localised strings that document the command-line options and commands. This object is passed in to the FieldNameDoc methods described in the documentation for . This should be null for monoligual applications.
Specifies a callback which is invoked on every documentation string retrieved from the s to generate the help text. This callback can modify the text arbitrarily.
member.returns: An instance of the class containing the options and parameters specified by the user on the command line.

member.summary: Parses the specified command-line arguments into an instance of the specified type. In case of failure, prints usage information to the console and returns default(TArgs). See the remarks section of the documentation for for features and limitations.

member.name: M:RT.Util.CommandLine.CommandLineParser.Colorize(RT.Util.RhoElement)
member.summary: Converts the specified parse tree into a console colored string according to CommandLineParser-specific rules. This method is used to convert documentation into colored text. See Remarks.
member.remarks: A number of named tags have a special meaning. Any tag named after a value of results in that color. Both spellings of gray/grey are supported. The {h}...{} named tag stands for the highlight color (white). {nowrap}...{} can be placed around text that must not be broken into multiple lines by the word wrapper. The tags {field}, {option}, {command} and {enum} are used to refer to the corresponding command line syntax element, and is highlighted the same way the documentation generator would highlight references to these entities.

member.name: M:RT.Util.CommandLine.CommandLineParser.Colorize(RT.Util.EggsNode)
member.summary: Converts the specified parse tree into a console colored string using the rules described in . This method is used to convert documentation into colored text, as well as any documentation using the legacy .

member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the user can give the focus to this control using the TAB key. This property’s value automatically changes every time Text changes; it is set to true if there is a link in the text, false otherwise. To achieve deviant behaviour, set TabStop immediately after setting Text.

member.summary: Forces an update of the off-screen buffer, by invoking the event. Then forces a normal refresh of the underlying panel, which causes the off-screen buffer to be repainted over the whole panel.

member.name: P:RT.Util.Controls.LabelEx.Text
member.summary: Text displayed in the label. See remarks for EggsML supported. Setting this property also changes the value of the property depending on whether the text contains any links. To achieve deviant behaviour, set TabStop immediately after setting Text.

item.description: * = bold.
/ = italics.
_ = underline.
+ = marks a section of text as nowrap.
<XYZ>{ ... } = make the text enclosed in curlies a link. XYZ can be any string and will be passed in for the event.
<XYZ>= ... = = colour the text enclosed in equals sign in the colour designated by XYZ (e.g. “Red”).
[ ... ] = adds a bullet point to the beginning of a paragraph. (Enclose the entire paragraph without its trailing newline, otherwise behaviour is weird.)

member.name: P:RT.Util.Controls.LabelEx.TabStop
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the user can give the focus to this control using the TAB key. This property’s value automatically changes every time Text changes; it is set to true if there is a link in the text, false otherwise. To achieve deviant behaviour, set TabStop immediately after setting Text.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Drawing.TextAnchor
member.summary: Specifies text alignment for .

summary.para: Wraps a to provide a hopefully more convenient interface. The major bits of functionality are:

item.description: all coordinates in doubles or structs;
support for the Y axis growing upwards;
functions targeted at drawing a 2d world onto a viewport of a specified size.
Rectangular area that will be the final destination of the drawing.
The region, defined in terms of the world coordinates, that is viewable on the screen.
Coordinates of the underlying "world" being represented.
Coordinates on the screen, can be used to directly draw on the underlying Graphics.
World X, Y, Width, Height, respectively
Screen X, Y, Width, Height, respectively

member.name: F:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.Graphics
member.summary: The underlying Graphics. All the actual drawing is done onto this instance.

member.summary: Selects a coordinate axes mode.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.ScreenSize
member.summary: Stores the screen size. "Screen" here refers to the final surface that this Canvas is destined for. The screen size is used for "set viewport" methods which do not take a screen location: they assume the relevant screen edge is meant instead.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.DefaultFont
member.summary: The font to be used by text drawing functions if no font is specified.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.#ctor
member.summary: Creates an instance without initializing any of the required fields.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.#ctor(System.Drawing.Graphics)
member.summary: Creates an instance using the specified Graphics as the underlying drawing surface.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.#ctor(System.Drawing.Graphics,System.Drawing.Size)
member.summary: Creates an instance using the specified graphics and screenSize. See for more info.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.ResetViewport
member.summary: Resets the scaling and offset so that world coordinates correspond to screen pixels. Maintains the offsets so that all visible pixels have positive coordinates and one of the corners is 0,0.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.SetViewport(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Sets the viewport so that the specified world coordinate is in the centre of the viewable screen, using the specified scaling factor.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.SetViewport(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sets the scaling and offset so that the world coordinate "leftWX" corresponds to the leftmost coordinate on the screen, world "topWY" to the topmost screen coordinate, etc. If "maintainAspect" is "true", ensures that X and Y scaling is the same, by making one of the axes show more than implied by the arguments passed in.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.MoveViewport(System.Single,System.Single,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Adjusts the offsets so that the world coordinate wx,wy is at the screen coordinate sx,sy. Does not modify the scaling.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.SX(System.Double)
member.summary: Converts world X coordinate into screen X. Screen X is zero at the leftmost pixel and Screen.Width at the rightmost pixel.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.SY(System.Double)
member.summary: Converts world Y coordinate into screen Y. Screen Y is zero at the topmost pixel and Screen.Height at the bottommost pixel.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.SW(System.Double)
member.summary: Converts world width into screen width. Screen width is measured in pixels.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.SH(System.Double)
member.summary: Converts world height into screen height. Screen height is measured in pixels.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.SP(RT.Util.Geometry.PointD)
member.summary: Converts a world point to a screen point.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.sa(System.Double)
member.summary: For internal use only. Converts world angle into screen angle as understood by GDI routines.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.sTop(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: For internal use only. Given two world coordinates, one known to be smaller than the other one, returns the one that would be higher on the screen, converted to screen coordinates.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.WX(System.Single)
member.summary: Converts screen X coordinate into world X. Screen X is zero at the leftmost pixel and Screen.Width at the rightmost pixel.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.WY(System.Single)
member.summary: Converts screen Y coordinate into world Y. Screen Y is zero at the topmost pixel and Screen.Height at the bottommost pixel.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.WW(System.Single)
member.summary: Converts screen width into world width. Screen width is measured in pixels.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.WH(System.Single)
member.summary: Converts screen height into world height. Screen height is measured in pixels.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.WP(System.Drawing.PointF)
member.summary: Converts a screen point to a world point.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.Clear(System.Drawing.Color)
member.summary: Fills the entire "screen" with the specified color.

member.summary: Draws a straight line using the specified pen.

member.summary: Draws a straight line using the specified pen.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.DrawLine(System.Drawing.Pen,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Draws a straight line using the specified pen.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Forms.DlgMessage
member.summary: Holds a number of settings that define a message dialog. Provides a method to show the dialog represented, as well as static methods to show some common dialog kinds with most settings at their defaults.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Forms.DlgMessage.Type
member.summary: Specifies the message type. This selects a sound, an image and a caption to be used by default, unless explicitly overridden in the other fields of this class. Defaults to .

member.name: F:RT.Util.Forms.DlgMessage.Buttons
member.summary: Specifies the labels of the buttons to be displayed in the dialog. Defaults to null, in which case a single "OK" button will appear. May contain at most four elements. The labels may include the ampersand to indicate a shortcut key, or double-ampersand to include an ampersand.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Forms.DlgMessage.Message
member.summary: Specifies the message to be displayed in the main message area. Defaults to null, in which case the message area will be empty.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Forms.DlgMessage.Format
member.summary: Specifies whether the text in this message box should be rendered using EggsML or plain text.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Forms.DlgMessage.Caption
member.summary: Specifies a caption to be displayed in the dialog's window title bar. Defaults to null, which means choose a title based on the field.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Forms.DlgMessage.Image
member.summary: Specifies an image to be displayed in the image area of the dialog. Defaults to null, which means use an image based on the field. If the type is , and this field is null, no image will be displayed.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Forms.DlgMessage.Font
member.summary: Specifies a font to be used for the message text (but not the buttons). Defaults to null, which means the default system font should be used.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Forms.DlgMessage.AcceptButton
member.summary: Specifies the index of the accept button (the one selected if the user just presses Enter). Defaults to -1, which means the button with index 0.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Forms.DlgMessage.CancelButton
member.summary: Specifies the index of the cancel button (the one selected if the user just presses Esc or Alt+F4). Defaults to -1, which means the button with the largest valid index.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Forms.DlgMessage.ShowInTaskbar
member.summary: Specifies whether a taskbar icon is shown for the dialog box.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Forms.DlgMessage.Show
member.summary: Shows a message using all the settings specified in this class instance. Anything left at defaults will be modified to hold the appropriate value. Any invalid settings will be flagged with an exception.

member.summary: Override to alter the window size, maximize state and/or position on first show and screen resolution changes. At the time of call, the current position/state/size are already set to the preferred ones, so it is possible to change them with respect to the "saved" values. member.name: T:RT.Util.Forms.ManagedWindow
member.summary: A window which has all the proper minimize/restore methods, and which remembers its position and size between instances of the application. The size/position/state values are automatically reflected in the settings object whenever the user resizes or moves the window. If XAML supplies an initial size, that size will be used whenever no previous size is available (such as first run).

member.name: P:RT.Util.Forms.ManagedWindow.MaximizedByDefault
member.summary: To make the window maximized by default (i.e. on first run, before the user has had a chance to move/resize the window), override this property and return true. This property is read from the window constructor. Do not use XAML to set Maximized to true because will not be able to override that without flicker (and thus doesn't support that at all).

member.summary: Provides very simple and easy-to-use methods to run an HTTP request and receive the response.

member.summary: Specifies the default root URL. See for more information.

member.summary: Specifies the default logger. See for more information.

member.summary: Contains the cookies to be sent to the server and received from the server.

member.name: F:RT.Util.HClient.Log
member.summary: Specifies a logger that logs all outgoing requests and responses.

member.name: P:RT.Util.HClient.ReqHeaders
member.summary: Exposes a collection of request headers. See Remarks.
member.remarks: HttpWebRequest labels certain headers "restricted" and requires them to be modified by modifying request properties, rather than setting values via the Headers collection. This class unrestricts some of those headers, specifically: Accept, Host, Referer, TransferEncoding, UserAgent. Some of the restricted headers are only supported partially, indirectly or via properties, specifically: Connection, ContentType, ContentLength, Expect. The remaining restricted headers cannot currently be modified at all, specifically: Date, IfModifiedSince, ProxyConnection, Range

member.name: P:RT.Util.HClient.ReqAccept
member.summary: A shorthand for getting and setting ReqHeaders[HttpRequestHeader.Accept]. Defaults to what a recent version of US Firefox might send.

member.name: P:RT.Util.HClient.ReqAcceptLanguage
member.summary: A shorthand for getting and setting ReqHeaders[HttpRequestHeader.AcceptLanguage]. Defaults to what a recent version of US Firefox might send.

member.name: P:RT.Util.HClient.ReqUserAgent
member.summary: A shorthand for getting and setting ReqHeaders[HttpRequestHeader.UserAgent] Defaults to what a recent version of US Firefox might send..

member.name: P:RT.Util.HClient.ReqReferer
member.summary: A shorthand for getting and setting ReqHeaders[HttpRequestHeader.Referer]. Defaults to null

member.name: P:RT.Util.HClient.Timeout
member.summary: Specifies how long to wait for the server to respond to the request before throwing an exception. Defaults to 10 seconds.

member.name: P:RT.Util.HClient.AllowAutoRedirect
member.summary: Specifies whether the receipt of a redirect should automatically generate a new request for the new URL. Defaults to false.

member.name: P:RT.Util.HClient.AutomaticDecompression
member.summary: Specifies which compression methods are supported. This affects the Accept-Encoding header and automatically decompresses the response if necessary. Defaults to gzip+deflate, as used by modern browsers.

member.name: P:RT.Util.HClient.KeepAlive
member.summary: Specifies whether to use keep-alive for follow-up requests. Defaults to true.

member.name: P:RT.Util.HClient.Expect100Continue
member.summary: Specifies whether to use Expect: 100 (continue) for post requests, thus querying the server for whether it wants to accept the post request, before sending the request body. Defaults to false. If true, the entire interaction is handled transparently.

member.name: F:RT.Util.HClient.RootUrl
member.summary: Specifies the root URL. If the request URL begins with http:// or https://, this is ignored. Otherwise the URL is prepended with this value.

member.returns: The response received from the server.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Lingo.Lingo
member.summary: Static class with helper methods to support multi-language applications.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Lingo.Lingo.AlsoSaveTranslationsTo
member.summary: If not null, whenever a translation is saved, Lingo will also attempt to save it in this directory. Use an absolute path. Lingo will quietly ignore any errors when saving here, and will do nothing if the path is missing. Lingo will overwrite read-only files without prompts.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Lingo.Lingo.LoadTranslationOrDefault``1(System.String,RT.Util.Lingo.Language@)
member.summary: Attempts to load the translation for the specified module and language. The translation must exist in the application executable directory under a subdirectory called "Translations". If the translation loaded successfully, returns the translation instance. Otherwise, the default constructor is called and the result returned, and is set to the default language returned by this constructor.
member.typeparam: The type of the translation class to load the translation into.
member.param: The name of the module whose translation to load.
The language code of the language to load. This is set to the default language if the specified language cannot be loaded.
member.returns: The loaded or default translation.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Lingo.Lingo.LoadTranslation``1(System.String,RT.Util.Lingo.Language)
member.summary: Loads and returns the translation for the specified module and language. The translation must exist in the application executable directory under a subdirectory called "Translations". If the translation cannot be loaded successfully, an exception is thrown.
member.typeparam: The type of the translation class to load the translation into.
member.param: The name of the module whose translation to load.
The language code of the language to load.
member.returns: The loaded translation.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Lingo.Lingo.LoadTranslation(System.Type,System.String,RT.Util.Lingo.Language)
member.summary: Loads and returns the translation for the specified module and language. The translation must exist in the application executable directory under a subdirectory called "Translations". If the translation cannot be loaded successfully, an exception is thrown.
member.param: The type of the translation class to load the translation into.
The name of the module whose translation to load.
The language code of the language to load.
member.returns: The loaded translation.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Lingo.Lingo.SaveTranslation``1(System.String,``0)
member.summary: Writes the specified translation for the specified module to an XML file in the application directory.
member.typeparam: Translation class to write.
member.param: Name of the module for which this is a translation.
The translation to save.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Lingo.Lingo.SaveTranslation(System.Type,System.String,RT.Util.Lingo.TranslationBase)
member.summary: Writes the specified translation for the specified module to an XML file in the application directory.
member.param: Translation class to write.
Name of the module for which this is a translation.
The translation to save.

member.summary: Returns the language from the enum which corresponds to the specified ISO code, or null if none matches.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Emailer
member.summary: Implements a simple interface for sending an email that shares a global repository of SMTP settings. This repository is stored using using the name "RT.Emailer". The repository contains a list of SMTP accounts with a unique name. One of the accounts may be designated as the default one if the application doesn't specify any. The "From" address is fixed per account, but the name may be overridden by the application.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Emailer.Log
member.summary: If set, the SMTP client will log various messages to this log at various verbosity levels.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Emailer.SendEmail(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Net.Mail.MailAddress},System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Sends an email using one of the pre-configured RT.Emailer SMTP accounts. If none are configured on this computer, an exception will be thrown, describing what the user needs to do - though this requires a pretty technical user.
member.param: The recipients of the email.
Subject line.
Body of the message in plaintext format, or null to omit this MIME type.
Body of the message in HTML format, or null to omit this MIME type.
The name of one of the RT.Emailer accounts to use (case-sensitive). If null or not defined, will fall back to exe name, then the Default Account setting, and then any defined account, in this order.
The text to use as the "from" name. If null, will use the executable name. This setting has no effect if the specified RT.Emailer account specifies a FromName of its own.

member.name: T:RT.Util.SettingsBase
member.summary: Provides a base class for settings classes, implementing certain common usage patterns. See remarks for detailed usage instructions.

remarks.para: Derive a class from this one and add the fields you wish to persist. Mark those you don't want stored with the . You must mark the derived class with .
Once the above is done, the settings can be saved by calling /, depending on intent. To load, call , making sure that the generic type is the type of your descendant class. For example:
implements an extra method to enable settings to be queued for a save on a separate thread, to reduce the performance impact of less important saves.

member.name: F:RT.Util.SettingsBase._lock
member.summary: Lock object used to protect concurrent access.

member.name: F:RT.Util.SettingsBase._saveThread
member.summary: The thread on which the background saving is performed.

member.name: M:RT.Util.SettingsBase.BeforeSave
member.summary: This method is called just before the settings class is written out to disk, allowing any required changes to be made to the fields. The base implementation does nothing. Note that this may be called on a different thread than the one invoking a Save* operation (but the same as the thread performing the save immediately after this method returns).

member.name: M:RT.Util.SettingsBase.AfterLoad
member.summary: This method is called just before the settings class is restored from disk, allowing any required changes to be made to the fields. The base implementation does nothing.

summary.para: This method is fully compatible with , and will cancel any pending earlier (older) saves.
Saves the settings. Intended to be used whenever the settings are important enough to bug the user if this fails.
This method is fully compatible with , and will cancel any pending earlier (older) saves.
Saves the settings. Intended to be used whenever the settings are not important enough to bug the user if this fails.
This method is fully compatible with , and will cancel any pending earlier (older) saves.

member.name: T:RT.Util.SettingsThreadedBase
member.summary: Like , but implements an additional save method.

member.name: M:RT.Util.SettingsThreadedBase.CloneForSaveThreaded
member.summary: Must return a deep clone of this class. This will be used to create a snapshot of the settings at the time when is called.

summary.para: Saves the settings. Intended for frequent use at any point where it would make sense to commit settings, but would not make sense to bug the user about any failures. This method is like , except that the actual save occurs slightly later on a separate thread. The method returns as soon as returns.
Note that this method is NOT guaranteed to save settings, but it usually will. Make sure you call when you want to guarantee a save, especially just before the program terminates.

member.name: T:RT.Util.SettingsKind
member.summary: Determines what the settings in the settings file are logically "attached" to.

member.name: F:RT.Util.SettingsKind.MachineSpecific
member.summary: These settings are specific to a particular computer. In normal mode: shared among all user accounts, and do not roam. In portable mode: separate settings stored for every machine name; user account doesn't matter.

member.name: F:RT.Util.SettingsKind.UserSpecific
F:RT.Util.SettingsKind.UserAndMachineSpecific
member.summary: These settings are specific to a particular combination of user and machine. In normal mode: separate settings for each user account on each machine; will not roam. In portable mode: separate settings stored for every machine name; user account doesn't matter.

member.name: F:RT.Util.SettingsKind.Global
member.summary: These settings are intended to be global, with constraints imposed by reality. In normal mode: shared among all user accounts, and do not roam. In portable mode: always shared; user account and machine name do not matter.

member.name: T:RT.Util.SettingsOnFailure

member.name: F:RT.Util.SettingsOnFailure.DoNothing

member.name: F:RT.Util.SettingsOnFailure.Throw
member.summary: Throw an exception in case of failure

member.name: F:RT.Util.SettingsOnFailure.ShowRetryOnly
member.summary: Ask the user to retry or to skip operation. No exceptions thrown.

member.name: F:RT.Util.SettingsOnFailure.ShowRetryWithCancel

member.summary: Returns the full path and file name that should be used to store the settings class marked with this attribute.
